newsitem.title: USA: OPTIONS - Dlr/yen vols firm on slide below 118 yen.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS - Dlr/yen vols firm on slide below 118 yen.

text.p: Persistent weakness in the dollar lifted implied volatilities on shorter-dated dollar/yen options at midday in U.S. trading, traders said.
The dollar broke important support at 118 yen late in the European day, dragged down in part by weakness in mark/yen, which hit its lowest level in almost a year.
U.S. traders said yen calls were attracting a strong bid, resulting in hefty premiums on shorter dates out through two months.
"As we broke through 118 we just lost all the offers. Everyone is very jittery. No one really knows where the support levels are," said an options broker in New York.
Traders said the market was fearful of another swift drop in dollar/yen following the sharp selloff seen Friday and Monday.
"It could move very quickly, and that's what everyone is very concerned with," said the New York broker.
One-month dollar/yen volatility firmed to 10.5/10.9 percent from 9.7/9.9 percent Tuesday.
Interest in longer-dated options was comparatively light, traders said. One-year dollar/yen volatility was up 0.2 point at 9.5/9.7 percent.
Mark/yen volatility was quoted at 9.1/9.4 percent, down from 9.7/10.1 percent Tuesday.

Dollar weakness also was attributed to surprisingly weak U.S. inflation data released earlier in the day that cast fresh doubt on chances for another 25-basis-point hike in the federal funds rate when the Federal Open Market Committee meets next week, analysts said.
The U.S. producer price index fell 0.6 percent in April, with the core index minus food and energy down 0.1 percent.
However, some analysts downplayed the data's importance in light of Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan's recent comments that demand factors rather than inflation were of more immediate concern.
Dollar/mark volatilities were slightly lower after Bundesbank officials this morning expressed satisfaction with current exchange rates.
Spot has edged lower throughout the session and was recently bid at 1.6974 marks, with some analysts looking for a test of 1.6850 near term.
One-month implied volatility for dollar/mark was 8.6/9.0 percent, down about 0.2 point on the day.
